persona.name: Rosa Elena Méndez

occupation.title: Informal commerce vendor / small food stall owner
occupation.organization: Independent (stall in local tianguis / semi-fixed espacio in neighborhood mercado)
occupation.description: Rosa runs a small informal comida corrida and prepared-food stall in a busy neighborhood market and sells basic groceries on the side. She arrives early, prepares breakfast and a daily lunch menu (two main dishes + soup), and sells throughout the day. Her responsibilities include menu planning, buying produce wholesale at the central market, cooking, serving customers, providing informal credit to trusted neighbors, basic cash handling, and negotiating price/credit with suppliers. She keeps an informal ledger on a ruled notebook, communicates orders and supply needs via WhatsApp groups, and sometimes accepts phone preorders for pick-up. She occasionally helps stock a nearby abarrotes store and does room cleaning jobs on weekends to supplement income. Her main skills are practical cooking, small-scale inventory management, customer relationships, and informal bookkeeping. She deals with irregular demand, theft risk, and irregular cash flow; she balances prices to remain affordable while barely covering costs. She prefers hands-on work, multitasks constantly, and is valued by neighbors for home-style food and for offering small lines of credit.

persona.education: Completed preparatoria (high school). Did not pursue tertiary education due to need to work after high school. Attended evening courses intermittently later for bookkeeping basics and food handling certificates obtained informally through local workshops.
long_term_goals: Stabilize family finances so her two children can finish at least high school and, ideally, one can attend university technical training.
Formalize and expand her small food stall into a registered micromarket or daytime fondita with a fixed location and minimal hired help.
Own a modest, debt-free home in a safer neighborhood and have a small savings buffer for emergencies.
Become a respected vendor in the local market, known for a signature mole recipe and for treating customers like family.
See her mother in better health and help her have a comfortable retirement.
Pass on culinary knowledge to her children so at least one can take over the business if needed.
Gain enough stability to occasionally travel to the Gulf coast to visit relatives and take a short family vacation every few years.
Maintain close daily contact with extended family and be the center of family gatherings during holidays.
Ensure access to reliable healthcare for her household without catastrophic costs.
Learn to use digital tools better (WhatsApp Business, simple invoicing) to manage orders and small delivery requests.
persona.style: Warm, practical and animated in person. Speaks Mexican Spanish with a Puebla / central highlands accent and idioms like "¿qué onda?", "¡ahí te va!", and affectionate diminutives ("mijita", "compa"). Uses humor and nicknames to connect with customers. Frequently smiles and hands out small samples. Tends to speak quickly when busy, slows down when explaining recipes or family stories. Mannerisms include wiping hands on an apron when talking, tucking hair behind her ear, and tapping a small wooden spoon on the counter to call attention. Polite but direct: she'll say "no es posible" or "más tarde" when a request can't be met. Uses colloquial metaphors referencing family and food. When nervous or embarrassed, she laughs loudly and covers her mouth. She dresses practically: simple blouses, an apron, comfortable flats; prefers bright colors and floral patterns typical of neighborhood market vendors. Carrying a well-worn phone in a silicone case, a multi-pocket apron with a small pen and change, and a keychain with a saint medal. Speaks with warmth to elders, louder and more playful with children, and uses a firmer tone when teaching or reproving her teenage son. When discussing politics or corruption, her tone becomes measured and sometimes skeptical; when talking about family or faith, her voice softens and becomes more intimate.

traits: Warm and nurturing: makes others feel welcome, often treats customers like extended family.
Practical and resourceful: finds low-cost solutions and repurposes leftovers creatively.
Resilient: tolerates setbacks and recovers quickly after a bad sales day or a family expense.
Anxious about money: frequently worries about bills, school fees, and rising prices.
Sociable: enjoys chatting with regulars and neighbors, thrives on small talk and personal news.
Protective and loyal: defends family and close friends fiercely.
Traditional but adaptable: holds on to cultural and religious customs while learning to use digital tools for business.
Stubborn when necessary: will insist on a price or a way of doing things if she believes it's right.
Generous within limits: shares food and credit with trusted people, but conservative with strangers.
Pragmatic optimist: hopes things can improve and plans small steps to get there.
Impatient with bureaucracy and slow service: loses patience with government offices or long lines.
Cautious about strangers: polite but keeps a personal distance until trust is established.

big_five.openness: Medium. Enjoys new recipes and occasionally new music or phone features but values traditional routines and familiar tastes.
big_five.conscientiousness: High. Reliable with work habits, keeps a ledger, punctual for market set-up and customer orders, careful about food hygiene.
big_five.extraversion: Medium-High. Energized by interactions with customers and neighbors; enjoys gossip and communal events but also needs quiet moments at home.
big_five.agreeableness: High. Cooperative, helpful, willing to give small informal loans; prefers harmony though can confront unfairness.
big_five.neuroticism: Medium. Experiences worry and stress over finances and security; mood fluctuates with household pressures but manages emotions publicly with humor and faith.

interests: Cooking regional Puebla dishes, especially mole poblano and chiles en nogada variations.
Learning new quick recipes that can be adapted for daily menus.
Watching telenovelas and morning magazine shows for gossip and home tips.
Listening to regional Mexican music (banda, norteño) and old boleros while cooking.
Attending church on major feast days and joining informal prayer groups.
Following local market news and neighborhood WhatsApp groups.
Buying fresh produce early at the central mercado for best prices.
Watching boxing or futbol highlights when she has a break.
Collecting family recipes and small household hacks from neighbors.
Organizing family gatherings and holiday meals.
Bargain hunting for cookware and small appliances at Tianguis and Bodega stores.
Using WhatsApp to manage orders, family logistics and friend gossip.
Checking Facebook Marketplace for used kitchen equipment and clothes.
Listening to radio stations in the morning while preparing food.
Attending local fairs and patron saint celebrations with her children.
Caring for a small altar during Día de Muertos and keeping photos of deceased relatives.
Watching short recipe videos on Facebook and occasionally TikTok for new ideas.
Participating in neighborhood cooperatives informally when suppliers offer bulk discounts.
Collecting loyalty cards and using store credit when available.
Following local politicians' promises but judging them by visible results.
likes: Home-cooked mole with rice and warm tortillas.
Café de olla spiced with cinnamon and piloncillo in the mornings.
Fresh bolillos and pan dulce from the panadería where she has a small credit agreement.
Bright, floral blouses and comfortable aprons with pockets.
Giving small portions to children who pass by the stall.
When regular customers arrive and greet her family by name.
Quiet early mornings at the mercado before the crowds arrive.
Using a simple pen-and-notebook ledger; it feels secure and familiar.
Sundays when the whole family eats together after church.
Buying vegetables from the same vendor who always throws in an orange for the children.
Receiving remittances from a sister in the US that cover a school term.
Small celebratory expenses (a cake for a birthday, a new dress for a quinceañera).
Hand-me-down kitchen tools that still work well.
A clean, uncluttered stall; dislikes clutter that attracts pests.
Neighbors bringing home-cooked tamales for sharing during festivals.
Local radio hosts who mention neighborhood news.
Simple desserts like arroz con leche or flan as treats for family.
When municipal services fix a streetlight or clean a drainage in front of the stall.
Being asked for recipe tips by younger vendors.
Getting small verbal praise from older customers ('¡qué rico!').
Using cash for most purchases but occasionally receiving mobile payments when offered.
Buying seasonal fruits and making agua fresca to sell on hot days.
Having a reliable friend who can watch the stall for a short break.
Seeing children finish school and take pride in small academic achievements.
dislikes: High, sudden increases in the price of staples like oil, rice or chicken.
Police or municipal inspectors who fine informal vendors unexpectedly.
Customers who haggle aggressively or refuse to pay.
Having to close because of heavy rain or municipal clearing operations.
Complicated digital invoicing systems that expect legal registration.
Loud, aggressive panhandlers who scare away locals.
Being told she should "just register" without support or affordable options.
Corrupt local officials who take bribes or make false promises.
Seeing young people drop out of school to work without a plan.
Stores that sell spoiled produce at full price.
Having to go to a distant clinic for basic health services.
Gossip that harms a neighbor's reputation—tries to stay out of it but gets dragged in.
Social media posts that feel judgmental about poor families.
Complicated bank procedures that require time off work.
When a trusted supplier changes quality without warning.
People who promise to pick up orders and don't come.
Expensive children's extracurriculars that feel unattainable.
Crowds that push and disturb her food setup.
Neighbors who take advantage of informal credit and delay repayment.
Being lectured by strangers about how to run her life or business.
consumption_habits_and_brands: Buys wholesale produce at La Central de Abasto (local market) early in the morning to get better prices.
Prefers basic, low-cost brands for staples: economical vegetable oil, generic rice and beans, sugar in bulk.
Occasionally buys discounted cleaning products at Bodega Aurrerá or local mayorista stores.
Buys chicken and pork from the same trusted butcher who offers small credit.
Uses gas cylinders for cooking; shops at the neighborhood supplier and pays in cash monthly.
Buys children's clothes at the mercado or on sale racks rather than brand stores.
Occasionally purchases second-hand appliances through Facebook Marketplace.
Has a prepaid mobile plan; recharges at the corner store and uses data sparingly.
Pays electricity and water at OXXO or convenience shops to avoid bank lines.
Uses WhatsApp and Facebook rather than email; seldom uses formal banking apps.
Buys pan dulce from the same vendor who gives small discounts for regulars.
Uses local tortillería for daily tortillas rather than making them herself most days.
Prefers vendors that allow short-term credit rather than formal credit cards.
Occasionally treats family to a fast-food meal (taquería or small family restaurant) on pay days.
Buys inexpensive cosmetics (lipstick, nail polish) at local 'puesto' stalls for celebrations.

beliefs: Government should play a larger role in providing affordable healthcare and should not leave people to pay catastrophic bills.
Social programs that help the poor are necessary and should be protected because many families depend on them.
Small businesses and vendors like her keep neighborhoods alive and deserve protection from overregulation.
Corruption is a major problem at municipal and state levels and often eats up funds meant for ordinary people.
Good politicians are those who deliver visible improvements: fixed streets, cleaner parks, stable water supply.
Education is very important for children; even if she couldn't study further, she wants her kids to at least finish high school.
Work hard and be honest—those qualities are respected and ultimately rewarded even if slowly.
Family obligations come first: money, time and resources are prioritized for parents, grandparents and children's needs.
People who migrate to the United States often help their families with remittances and are making sacrifices.
Health clinics should be available and responsive; long waits and stock-outs of medicine are unacceptable.
Religious faith (Catholic traditions) offers comfort and community, though church attendance is flexible depending on work.
Women can work and be caretakers at the same time; a woman's job is compatible with motherhood though it's tiring.
Men should contribute to household expenses, but in practice she accepts the reality of irregular incomes and shares responsibilities.
It is better to save small amounts regularly than to keep no savings at all; savings of even modest size matter.
Neighbors and extended family form an essential safety net; reciprocal favors are part of daily life.
It's wise to lend small amounts to trusted neighbors, but large loans are risky and often lead to problems.
Voting matters because it can change local services, but past promises make her skeptical; she supports Morena for its social program rhetoric.
Public pensions and subsidies for vulnerable groups are important; the state has a role in redistribution.
Police are necessary but sometimes unreliable; community safety often depends on neighborhood vigilance.
Traditional gender roles remain influential but younger generations show different expectations about women's work.
Healthcare prevention (vaccination, prenatal care) is important though access and information vary; she vaccinates her children and got COVID shots.
Plastic waste is visible in the neighborhood but immediate survival and cost are prioritized over environmental issues.
Local festivals and religious events are crucial for social cohesion and maintaining identity.
Young people should be encouraged to train in practical trades (carpentry, mechanics, cooking) that provide immediate income.
Debt from tienda credit, microloans, and family loans can be a lifeline but also a trap if not managed carefully.
Small entrepreneurial initiatives need simplified access to registration and microcredit to survive and grow.
Childcare is a bottleneck for working mothers; flexible school hours and community babysitting help.
Public transport affordability and reliability are central concerns; long bus trips reduce ability to work multiple jobs.
Municipal services that reduce petty crime (lighting, drainage) are more effective than occasional police patrols.
Food is central to family life and identity; cooking at home is healthier and more economical when possible.
Banks and formal financial institutions feel distant and sometimes hostile; informal saving circles (tandas) are preferred by many neighbors.
Mental health is real but stigmatized; people prefer to cope within family and faith communities than seek professional help.
Women vendors are resilient but face harassment and unequal treatment; safety in markets is an ongoing worry.
Young people leaving the area for seasonal work is normal and sometimes necessary for family survival.
She believes in second chances and will give people opportunities to pay back debts if they show good faith.
Public schools should improve resources and teacher support; school supplies and uniforms are recurring burdens on budgets.
Civic participation (neighborhood assemblies) can help push small changes when residents are organized.
Access to clean water and waste collection should be prioritized by local authorities.
Food labeling and price transparency would help households stretch limited budgets.
skills: Culinary skills: prepares traditional Puebla dishes (mole, tamales, stews) and adapts recipes for daily sale with consistent portions.
Small-scale inventory and stock rotation: knows how to avoid spoilage and use day-old items creatively.
Informal bookkeeping: maintains a black-and-white ledger with daily takings, petty expenses and informal credit entries.
Customer service: builds rapport quickly, remembers regulars' preferences and uses nicknames to strengthen loyalty.
Bargaining and supplier negotiation: strong at haggling and securing small credit from wholesalers.
Basic food hygiene: uses common-sense practices to avoid contamination and manage hot-holding.
Time management under pressure: coordinates cooking, serving and buying tasks during market hours smoothly.
Basic mobile communication: proficient with WhatsApp, can send voice notes, photos of orders and coordinate pickups.
Multi-tasking manual skills: chopping, stirring, serving quickly while speaking to customers.
Budget stretching: plans menus and portions to keep costs low while maintaining acceptable taste and quality.
Problem-solving: finds quick substitutions for missing ingredients and improvises when a tool breaks.
Community networking: organizes small cooperative buys with other vendors to reduce costs.
Child supervision while working: combines work with overseeing children's homework and routines.
Informal marketing: uses word-of-mouth, small handwritten signs, and sample tastes to attract customers.
Basic household maintenance: minor plumbing fixes, sewing, patching aprons and clothes herself.

general: Greets each regular customer by name and asks about their family.
Offers a free small taste to new passersby to convert them into repeat customers.
Leaves the cash in a hidden pouch when stepping away briefly rather than a visible tray.
Writes daily on a small ruled notebook first thing in the morning: menu, expected purchases, and informal credit notes.
Prays briefly before meals and on important days; places a small saint medal near her cash box.
Keeps a plastic tub with wet wipes for quick cleaning and uses lemon water for counters at the end of the day.
When sales are low, reduces portions slightly rather than raise prices abruptly to keep customers.
Shares leftover soup or small portions with a neighbor in need rather than waste the food.
Checks WhatsApp groups several times a day for orders, supply alerts and neighborhood messages.
Complains about municipal fees and sudden inspections with other vendors but usually pays fines if levied.

morning: Wakes at 4:45 AM to prepare dough for tortillas or masa-based fillings on market days.
Has a quick café de olla and a bolillo while planning the day's menu.
Leaves the house by 5:30 AM to buy fresh vegetables and meat at the central market before peak crowds.
Sets up the stall by 6:30 AM, lights the gas burners and begins preparing breakfast items for early workers.
Checks messages and confirms any preorders received overnight via WhatsApp.
workday: Serves breakfast customers from 6:30 to 8:30 AM, then switches to the comida corrida menu for workers and families.
Balances cash frequently, writes sales in the notebook and keeps receipts folded in a small envelope.
Runs small errands mid-morning (buy ice, spices, or change) if needed; sometimes borrows change at a nearby tienda.
Offers informal credit to regular customers who promise to pay at the end of the week.
Closes the stall around 6:00 PM, cleans utensils, stores leftovers safely and updates the ledger with the day's totals.
evening: Arrives home by 7:30 PM, prepares a small family dinner, and listens to children's school stories.
Helps children with homework or checks their notebooks; sometimes calls a teacher via phone to ask about progress.
Spends 30 minutes reviewing the next day's supply needs and prices.
Prays or watches a short telenovela episode with her husband before bed.
Goes to bed around 10:30–11:00 PM, often replaying the day's conversations and plans mentally.
weekend: On Saturdays, visits wholesale suppliers for bulk purchases and sometimes helps her husband with a side hustle.
On Sundays, attends morning Mass when schedule allows and participates in family lunch gatherings.
Occasionally spends Sunday afternoons at a relative's house for extended family visits or neighborhood fiestas.
Uses one weekend a month for paperwork errands (municipal payments, ID renewals) and health clinic visits.

health.physical: Generally robust but with signs of wear from years of standing and lifting: mild lower back pain, occasional knee discomfort, and slightly elevated BMI consistent with a busy, carbohydrate-rich diet. Dental health is poor: missing a molar and irregular dental visits due to cost. Has seasonal allergies and occasional gastritis flares when she eats late or under stress.
health.mental: Moderate stress related to financial uncertainty and household responsibilities. Shows resilience and a pragmatic outlook but experiences sleeplessness and worrying bouts, especially when a child needs school supplies or a large unexpected expense appears. Uses family, prayer and social contact as primary coping mechanisms.
health.medical_history: Had an uncomplicated pregnancy with both children. Received standard childhood vaccinations and has been vaccinated for COVID-19 with two doses and a booster. Treated a bout of dengue fever years ago with outpatient care. No chronic diabetes diagnosis but monitors diet due to family history; had a blood pressure reading once slightly high and is monitoring it at home informally.
health.access_to_care: Uses the local public clinic (clinic estatal / Seguro Popular legacy clinics or IMSS-Bienestar services) for primary care and vaccinations. Prefers public services due to cost; resorts to private clinics for urgent needs when funds allow. Supports stronger government-run health services and believes clinics should stock essential medicines consistently.
health.health_behaviors: Attempts to include vegetables daily in family meals, limits fried food for children, uses boiled water for drinks at home, and keeps basic first-aid supplies. Avoids heavy alcohol, does not smoke, and encourages children to practice good hygiene.

relationships.name: José Méndez (husband)
relationships.description: Age 38, works irregularly in construction and small day labor. Cooperative household partner who helps with heavy lifting and occasionally manages suppler deliveries. Relationship is stable but both worry about irregular incomes. Shares childcare duties and decision-making on major expenses.

relationships.name: María (mother, 58)
relationships.description: Lives nearby, helps with childcare and occasionally prepares tamales for sale during special occasions. Has chronic arthritis and depends partly on family support. Respected elder voice in the household.

relationships.name: Luis (son, 14)
relationships.description: Attends secondary school, helps after school by running errands and doing small tasks at the stall. Studious but sometimes tempted by part-time work; Rosa insists he finish school.

relationships.name: Sofía (daughter, 9)
relationships.description: Attends primary school, likes helping set tables at the stall and distributing drinks to customers. Protective older brother and many neighbors dote on her.

relationships.name: Ana (younger sister)
relationships.description: Migrated temporarily to the United States years ago, sends remittances occasionally which have helped pay for big school expenses and a small roof repair. Keeps close contact via WhatsApp and sends pictures of her children.

relationships.name: Doña Carmen (neighbor and market friend)
relationships.description: Runs the adjacent vegetable stand, supplies Rosa with discounted produce when she buys in bulk together; they share gossip, childcare favors and rotate market watches for short breaks.

relationships.name: Don Arturo (trusted butcher)
relationships.description: Supplies meat on a small-credit basis; accepts later payment for trusted customers like Rosa. Relationship built over many years of mutual respect.

relationships.name: Small circle of regulars
relationships.description: A group of 6–8 regular customers who socialize around Rosa's stall, exchange news, occasionally bring a fruit basket or small gifts, and are her main weekday clientele.

relationships.name: Local church community
relationships.description: Attends major services and participates in shared meals and prayer requests; the network provides emotional and occasional financial informal support.

relationships.name: Schoolteachers
relationships.description: Respectful pragmatic relationships; Rosa contacts them when she is concerned about her children's progress and sometimes helps organize small fundraising for class events.

other_facts: Born and raised in a suburban barrio of Puebla; childhood home was modest with a mother who cooked and a father who worked as a bus driver.
One of four siblings; the household emphasized mutual aid and practical skills like cooking, sewing and bargaining.
Married her husband in her early 20s after they worked together at a neighborhood tienda; chose an informal union ceremony followed by a modest family reception.
Learned to cook from her mother and grandmother; the mole recipe she uses is an adaptation blending family techniques and cheaper shortcuts to keep costs manageable.
At 16 she left school briefly to help at home when her father lost work; returned to finish preparatoria later while working part-time at a bakery.
Her eldest child, Luis, is proud when customers compliment the food and sometimes translates numbers and messages on her phone to help with orders.
Once took a small microloan to pay for a refrigerator after a heatwave spoiled stock, repaid it over nine months with careful budgeting.
Saved for two years to pay for her daughter's first communion and a modest dress, relying on remittances and small lending circles among women vendors.
Has been part of a local tanda (rotating savings group) twice, which helped with school fees and a stove purchase; values the mutual trust but worries about defaults.
Was briefly involved in a neighborhood vendor association to negotiate market space; the experience taught her about local politics and the costs of activism.
Survived a house roof leak that required scraping together funds and help from neighbors to repair; the community pitched in with labor and second-hand materials.
Her stall's name—handwritten on a faded sign—mentions 'La Casa de Rosa' and is familiar to older neighbors as a dependable place for a hot plate.
Once had a conflict with a municipal inspector who threatened fines; resolved it by paying a small informal fee and later organizing neighbors to demand clearer rules.
Keeps a small box with older coins and folded bills as an emergency fund; it's hidden inside a prayer book.
Has a childhood memory of a grandfather who would tell stories about Puebla's fiestas and who taught her the value of hospitality.
She and her husband once considered moving to a cheaper neighborhood but decided the market location and social ties here were more valuable than lower rent elsewhere.
Her husband was injured in a minor construction accident years ago; they paid out-of-pocket for a short private consultation and then followed up at the public clinic.
Participates each year in preparing offerings for Día de Muertos and involves the children in making paper flowers and decorating an altar.
Proud of being able to send money for her sister's child's school uniform despite her own economic constraints; considers remittances a family investment.
Attended a municipal entrepreneurship workshop where she learned about food safety basics and was given a certificate she keeps laminated.
Has a box of old recipe cards with notes in the margins about which ingredients to substitute when money is tight.
Once organized a small neighborhood potluck when a neighbor lost their job; the event strengthened local reciprocal ties.
Remembers the first time a customer complimented her mole and told her 'you should open a restaurant'—a compliment she still treasures and uses as motivation.
Kept a diary of expenses for a challenging year after a bad storm and now uses that memory to avoid impulsive purchases.
Sells more food during rainy months because construction workers seek hot meals; conversely, sales dip when many neighbors leave for seasonal work.
Her children know the names of many regular customers and treat them like aunts and uncles; this social familiarity helps business and family security.
Once borrowed a friend's blender to prepare aguas frescas for a festival and returned it with a small bag of pastries as thanks; such reciprocity matters.
Has a vivid memory of a teacher who encouraged her literacy and gave her the confidence to keep a ledger despite low formal education.
Fears a fire at the stall and keeps a small extinguisher and a bucket of sand nearby; has practiced quick shutdown routines with nearby vendors.
Values photographs: has a small album showing family milestones, which she shows proudly to curious customers.
Was mildly ill with COVID-19 in 2020, recovered at home with support from relatives, and now speaks about the importance of vaccination to hesitant neighbors.
Is learning to use WhatsApp Business features slowly after seeing a younger cousin use it to coordinate cake orders and small deliveries.
Her favorite kitchen utensil is an old wooden spoon given by her grandmother, used for stirring moles and stews; she keeps it polished.
Keeps small ritual practices: crosses herself before handling money and places a coin on the altar when a sale goes well as thanks.
Once helped a teenage neighbor sign up for a vocational course at a local CETIS center and celebrates the neighbor's subsequent job placement.
Remembers a time when the mercado organized an emergency fund for a vendor with a sick child; such collective actions left a lasting impression.
Has a long-standing mild fear of being robbed while carrying cash; usually transfers cash home in smaller amounts to reduce risk.
Occasionally participates in a women's sewing circle where members repair aprons and make simple goods to sell during festivals.
Knows the municipal clinic nurses by name and trusts them for vaccinations and childhood check-ups; however, she still prefers private labs for urgent blood tests when she can pay.
Has a small collection of recipes adapted to low-cost ingredients that she swaps with other vendors when inputs are scarce.
Would like to tape-record her mother's stories to preserve family memory but has not found the time or equipment.
Feels pride in being able to provide daily food, school supplies and a stable roof despite persistent financial insecurity.
